Award.AwardTitle: HF Backscatter from the Polar and Auroral E-Region Ionosphere: Origin, Conjugacy, and Electric Field Control
Award.AbstractNarration: The project will focus on investigations into the largely unexplored subset of coherent echo returns from the polar and auroral E-region plasma waves observed with the first U.S. Antarctic high-frequency ionospheric radar deployed at McMurdo in early 2010 in conjunction with other Antarctic and high northern hemisphere radars within the SuperDARN international program. Recent body of work on auroral E-region irregularities exploring SuperDARN as a global array has clearly demonstrated importance of the aspect angle or, equivalently, magnetic inclination angle conditions for both occurrence and phase velocity of E-region radar aurora. Initial observations by the McMurdo radar show abundance of short-range echoes with properties very similar to auroral E-region echoes but at locations with very high geometric aspect angles. The project's research will address a fundamental question of why E-region echoes from the polar cap are observed at all by the McMurdo radar. These investigations will include further examination of the previously found auroral echoes with unusual properties, e.g., velocities greatly exceeding nominal ion-acoustic speed and independent of the plasma flow angle. They will also evaluate the extent of magnetic conjugacy of the E-region radar aurora and establish the relationship between E-region irregularities and plasma drift velocities. This research will be led by a new young PI and will also contribute to the training and education of a graduate student.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The intellectual merit of the work supported by this award derives from analysis of the largely unexplored subset of radar returns from the two US upper atmospheric radars at the McMurdo and South Pole Antarctic stations in conjunction with other Antarctic and high northern latitude radars within the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network (SuperDARN). The conducted research broadly falls within two groups of studies: (1) analysis of radar observations of small-scale waves in the plasma density within the Earth’s upper atmosphere and (2) improvement of theoretical understanding of their generation and characteristics. These plasma waves are important since they represent a major source of degradation of radio communication signals, e.g. radio transmissions from navigation satellites and radar surveillance.

Within the first group of studies, an experimental investigation electron heating by plasma waves in the ionospheric E-region (100-120 km in altitude) was conducted which demonstrated unexpected saturation of electron temperatures at extreme electric fields owing to, in part, stronger vibrational cooling [Makarevich et al., 2013]. The E-region plasma wave characteristics observed by the SuperDARN radar at South Pole were found to be controlled by the convection electric field variations at South Pole [Makarevich et al., 2015a]. A unique experimental configuration where the same E-region locations were probed from two opposite directions by the SuperDARN radars in Antarctica was utilized to study E-region plasma waves and propagation conditions in the polar ionosphere. An unexpected feature of the E-region velocity-range profiles being reflections of each other was found and explained using a tilted ionosphere model [Forsythe and Makarevich, 2015]. Statistical occurrence of the E-region plasma waves was investigated using two SuperDARN South Pole and Zhongshan radars. It was demonstrated that the asymmetry in the E-region velocity distribution is highly sensitive to the bias in the plasma convection component and that the velocity distribution may also depend on the plasma wave height and the presence of strong density gradients modifying the plasma instability threshold value [Forsythe and Makarevich, 2017].

The second group of studies has been prompted by one unexpected outcome of the SuperDARN observations at South Pole, namely that radar echoes often occupied a broad range of altitudes. This is unexpected from theoretical point of view and, as a result, a general fluid theory has been developed that first resulted in a unified view of the gradient-drift instability across the entire lower ionosphere [Makarevich, 2014], which later has been expanded to include other fundamental ionospheric plasma instabilities in the broad range of altitudes [Makarevich, 2016a]. Analytic analysis of the general dispersion relation demonstrated strong inertial effects on decameter waves in the F region seen by SuperDARN [Makarevich, 2016b]. Using this general theory, it was also discovered that moderate-to-strong electric fields parallel to the magnetic field can result in experimentally measurable differences between the characteristics of plasma waves with parallel propagation components of opposite polarity [Forsythe and Makarevich, 2016].

Broader Impacts: This award has supported one PhD student at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (UAF) and has provided her dissertation topic. The outcomes of this award have also been used in classroom teaching at UAF.
